DOC.HEAD: Allegheny International Posts Net Loss of $36.7 Million
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International Inc. reported Thursday that its net loss nearly tripled in its fiscal fourth quarter from a year earlier. The small-appliance maker said it posted a net loss of $36.7 million, or $4.06 a share, in the three months ended Oct. 1, widened from a loss of $12.4 million, or $1.84 a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue fell to $207.4 million from $222.9 million. Allegheny International has operated under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for around two years. Earlier this month, a federal judge approved a $6.25 million settlement of shareholders' lawsuits from 1986 that accused some officers and directors of violating securities laws. Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs, once the largest shareholder in the company, recently sold all of his remaining shares. The company said the latest fourth-quarter results included charges of $21.1 million for plant rationalization, business restructuring and product writeoff costs. The same period a year earlier included $9.3 million in charges. For the fiscal year ended Oct. 1, Allegheny International posted a net loss of $54.9 million, or $7.80 a share, compared with a loss of $25.1 million, or $5.10 a share, a year earlier. Full-year revenue declined to $937.6 million from $967.8 million.
